pending_diagnosis: DIAGNOSIS: Acute Intermittent Porphyria (AIP) THE SMOKING GUN: The classic triad of symptoms—severe Abdominal Pain (without surgical findings), Psychosis/Encephalopathy, and Polyneuropathy—coupled with the acute onset of hypertension and tachycardia (autonomic instability) and the oxidized "port-wine" urine, provides the pathognomonic constellation of an acute porphyric attack. The trigger was likely the high stress level (a known metabolic trigger), or possibly an unlisted porphyrinogenic drug. PATHOPHYSIOLOGY: AIP is an autosomal dominant disease caused by a partial deficiency of the enzyme Porphobilinogen Deaminase (PBGD), the third enzyme in the hepatic heme biosynthetic pathway. When the pathway is induced (by stress, certain drugs, alcohol, or calorie restriction), the deficiency is overcome, leading to a profound buildup of neurotoxic precursors upstream of the block, specifically delta-aminolevulinic acid (ALA) and porphobilinogen (PBG). These high levels of circulating ALA and PBG are thought to exert direct toxic effects on the nervous system: 1. Autonomic Neuropathy: Causes the profound abdominal pain, severe hypertension, and tachycardia. 2. Peripheral Neuropathy: Causes the severe, rapidly ascending, potentially fatal flaccid paralysis. 3. Central Nervous System Toxicity: Causes the seizures, psychosis, and encephalopathy. The red-wine color in the urine is due to the spontaneous non-enzymatic conversion of PBG to porphobilin, which darkens upon exposure to light and air. Definitive diagnosis is made by measuring markedly elevated urinary ALA and PBG levels during the acute attack.
